channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2016 The New York Times Company

item.title: Iran’s Supreme Leader on America: Don’t Trust, Don’t Cooperate
item.description: A nationally televised speech by Ayatollah Ali Khamenei seemed to signal that Iran’s senior leadership would not allow any easing of hostility toward the United States.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: U.S. Sanctions Expected to Hit Small Banks’ Business With North Korea
item.media:description: Chinese guards at the North Korean Embassy in Beijing. The United States Treasury Department has designated North Korea as a “primary money-laundering concern.”
item.description: The Chinese banks most affected by the sanctions on Pyongyang will be regional ones that facilitate the bulk of North Korea’s business in China.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ

item.title: Moldova Is Rattled as Washington Welcomes a Feared Tycoon
item.media:description: Riot police officers scuffled with protesters near the home of Vladimir Plahotniuc in Chisinau, Moldova, in April.
item.description: Vlad Plahotniuc is so toxic even his political friends usually try to keep their distance in public, but a State Department official met with him.
item.dc:creator: ANDREW HIGGINS

item.title: German Parliament Recognizes Armenian Genocide, Angering Turkey
item.media:description: A protester held the German and Turkish flags outside the Parliament building in Berlin on Wednesday.
item.description: The Turkish government angrily denounced the vote as “null and void” and recalled its ambassador.
item.dc:creator: ALISON SMALE and MELISSA EDDY
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: How Will ‘Brexit’ Vote Go? Monty Python May Offer Clue
item.media:description: Delegates for the populist U.K. Independence Party, or UKIP, during their spring conference in Llandudno, Wales, in February. The party has pushed to leave the European Union.
item.description: Underneath the campaign’s theatrics lie questions of identity: Have Britons, many of whom see the European Union as a money-sucking abstraction, ever felt like part of Europe?
item.dc:creator: SARAH LYALL

item.title: Political Violence Roils the Republic of Congo
item.media:description: A burned police station in Brazzaville, Republic of Congo, on April 4.
item.description: Since the country’s longtime president was re-elected in March, humanitarian groups have reported airstrikes and ground offensives in opposition strongholds of the capital, Brazzaville.
item.dc:creator: MARGAUX BENN and CAROLINE CHAUVET
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Palestinians Elect a New President (on a Reality TV Show)
item.media:description: Security guards surrounded Waad Qannam, center with red tie, after he was announced as the show’s winner on Thursday.
item.description: “The President,” a reality show, allowed Palestinians to choose a leader, which they have not had the chance to do in more than a decade.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: U.N. Plans No Imminent Airdrops of Aid in Syria, Despite Expired Deadline
item.description: United Nations officials were cautious about the prospect of airdrops, saying that they would need the consent of the Syrian government.
item.dc:creator: NICK CUMMING-BRUCE and RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: Zika May Be Transmitted by Oral Sex, Scientists Find
item.description: The possibility was raised in a French case at a time when experts have come to believe that sexual transmission is an important driver of the virus.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.

item.title: France Hosts Talks on Restarting Mideast Peace Process
item.description: With tensions flaring between the Israelis and the Palestinians, France decided to propose a new process.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN

item.title: Why the Seine River Is Bursting Its Banks in Paris
item.media:description: Railways tracks were flooded near the Eiffel Tower on Friday after the rain-swollen Seine reached its highest level in three decades.
item.description: Not only has the Paris region been inundated by rain, but dams upstream were already near capacity.
item.dc:creator: DAPHNÉ ANGLÈS

item.title: Eerily Empty Louvre: What It’s Like When Floods Keep Tourists Away
item.media:description: Artworks were packed to be moved from the Louvre Museum’s storeroom to the exhibition halls, where they would be less vulnerable to rising flood waters.
item.description: Rooms packed with Renaissance masterpieces like the “Mona Lisa” were eerily empty on Friday, while others were filled with works moved to higher ground.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE

item.title: 24 Killed as Armed Protesters Clash With the Police in India
item.media:description: Fire engulfed buildings in Jawahar Bagh park in Mathura, India, that were used by a sect that fired on the police who were trying to evict them. At least 24 people were killed.
item.description: The violence, which left two top police officials dead and 23 officers wounded, occurred when authorities tried to evict the sect from a park in Mathura, India.
item.dc:creator: HARI KUMAR

item.title: The Saturday Profile: With Views From the Inside, an Activist Challenges Vietnam’s Rulers
item.media:description: Nguyen Quang A with his supporters in Hanoi, Vietnam, in April. He was invited to meet with President Obama, but the police barred him from coming.
item.media:credit: Hoang Dinh Nam/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Nguyen Quang A, an activist blocked from meeting with President Obama, says the Communist Party sometimes needs coaxing, and sometimes confrontation.
item.dc:creator: JANE PERLEZ
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations

item.title: Migrant Boat Capsizes off Crete, Killing at Least 4
item.media:description: The body of a migrant washed up on a beach in Zuwarah, Libya, on Thursday.
item.description: About 340 refugees were rescued and a search was underway after the vessel, which may have held 700 people, overturned en route to Italy from Egypt.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: In Paris, Seine River Rises to Highest Level Since 1982
item.media:description: The banks of the Seine on Friday. The river reached its highest level since 1982.
item.media:credit: Pierre Terdjman for The New York Times
item.description: The river was expected to crest on Friday evening at around 21 feet, still far short of the 26.2 feet reached in 1910.
item.dc:creator: LILIA BLAISE and BENOÎT MORENNE

item.title: Sinosphere: Remembering Tiananmen in Hong Kong, but Not Without Divisions
item.media:description: Lee Cheuk-yan, a member of the Legislative Council from the Labor Party and former chairman of the Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China, at the Legislative Council.
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.description: For years, activists, student leaders and politicians gathered to declare solidarity in a continuing struggle for political change in China. This year is different.
item.dc:creator: ALAN WONG
item.category: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China

item.title: Sinosphere: Getting Hitched in Beijing? Try to Look the Part, Please
item.media:description: A couple kissing at a marriage registry office in Beijing on Valentine’s Day.
item.description: The authorities in Beijing have determined that many couples showing up to register their marriages are just too casual.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Internet Speed Ranks 91st in the World
item.media:description: A woman on her phone in Pingyao, China. About half of the Chinese population is online, and 90 percent gain access to the internet via their phones.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: While trying to emphasize China’s connectivity, a report by a state newspaper acknowledged the creeping pace of connections in the country.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: Japanese Boy, 7, Left on Mountain by Parents Is Found Alive
item.media:description: Yamato Tanooka in an undated photo.
item.media:credit: Jiji Press, via Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.description: Missing for nearly a week, the boy was found in a cabin on a remote military base exhausted but apparently uninjured.
item.dc:creator: JONATHAN SOBLE

item.title: Mohammed Abdelaziz, Advocate of an Independent Western Sahara, Dies at 68
item.media:description: Mohammed Abdelaziz in 2014. He was the leader of the Polisario Front in Western Sahara.
item.description: The Polisario Front, led for four decades by Mr. Abdelaziz, has tried to establish a sovereign state for the disputed region’s Berber tribesmen.
item.dc:creator: CARLOTTA GALL

item.title: Belgium’s Interior Minister Visits New York Police to Discuss Terror Threats
item.media:description: Belgium’s interior minister, Jan Jambon, with John J. Miller, New York City’s deputy police commissioner for intelligence and counterterrorism, right, at a tour of a New York Police Department antiterrorism unit on Thursday.
item.description: The minister, Jan Jambon, expressed interest in the New York Police Department’s counterterrorism technology and bomb-sniffing dogs.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: For David Cameron, TV Appeal Against ‘Brexit’ Turns Tense
item.media:description: Prime Minister David Cameron of Britain spoke with members of the audience after a Sky News interview in London on Thursday.
item.media:credit: Chris Lobina/Sky News, via Getty Images
item.description: During a combative forum three weeks before Britain’s referendum, the prime minister pointed out the economic risks of quitting the European Union.
item.dc:creator: STEPHEN CASTLE

item.title: A Top Aide to Assad Takes Syria’s Case to a U.S. Audience
item.media:description: Bouthaina Shaaban, blacklisted by the United States, spoke via Skype during a news conference near the White House on Thursday.
item.description: Bouthaina Shaaban, speaking via Skype to a group including reporters near the White House, assailed the Obama administration and Western news media.
item.dc:creator: JULIE HIRSCHFELD DAVIS
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)

item.title: Germany Charges 4 Syrians in Plot to Attack Düsseldorf
item.description: Three Syrians who were arrested Thursday in Germany, plus one in custody in France, were charged in connection with a plan that involved suicide bombings, prosecutors said.
item.dc:creator: MELISSA EDDY
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: Edgar Feuchtwanger Bore Witness, Horribly Close to Hitler
item.media:description: Edgar Feuchtwanger during his recent visit to New York.
item.description: The writer and historian grew up perhaps 100 yards from Adolf Hitler during the Nazi era, before escaping Germany.
item.dc:creator: WILLIAM GRIMES

item.title: One Guantánamo Detainee Pleads for Release, but Another Does Not Appear
item.media:description: Mohamedou Ould Slahi
item.description: In one hearing, the author of a memoir about his time in prison was portrayed as a model prisoner, while elsewhere disruptions at the facility were described.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Brazil’s Soccer Prowess Has Been Consumed by Years of Neglect
item.media:description: Brazil was defeated by Paraguay in the quarterfinals of the 2015 Copa América.
item.description: As the Copa América Centenario kicks off this weekend and the Rio Olympics loom later this summer, Brazil’s national team is a shadow of its past.
item.dc:creator: EWAN MacKENNA

item.title: Where Did Dogs Come From? There May Be Two Answers.
item.media:description: Quincy, the dog, waits while Tammy and Tim Kelly enjoy cupcakes at the Frankenmuth Dog Bowl in Michigan. Two researchers argue that domestication of ancient wolves to modern day dogs happened in both Asia and Europe.
item.media:credit: Josie Norris/The Saginaw News, via MLive.com, via Associated Press
item.description: A scientist studying the origins of dogs suggests they may have been domesticated twice.
item.dc:creator: JAMES GORMAN
item.category: Far East, South and Southeast Asia and Pacific Areas

item.title: MacArthur Foundation Will Award $100 Million for Solution to a Global Problem
item.media:description: Julia Stasch of the MacArthur Foundation.
item.description: The prize will be given not to individuals or government entities, but to any nonprofit or for-profit organization that identifies a problem and offers a fix.
item.dc:creator: CHRISTINE HAUSER
item.category: MacArthur, John D and Catherine T, Foundation

item.title: Riding Out Storms, and Loneliness, in the Ocean Search for Flight 370
item.media:description: The Fugro Equator arriving before dawn in Fremantle, Australia, in early May after 43 days at sea searching for Malaysia Airlines Flight 370.
item.media:credit: David Parker for The New York Times
item.description: A ship’s 30-member crew has braved towering waves and other hazards as it looks for debris of the missing Malaysia Airlines jet on the ocean floor.
item.dc:creator: KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: As Bangladesh Counts Rohingya, Some Fear Forced Relocation
item.media:description: Rohingyas in a refugee camp in Bangladesh in 2015. About 32,000 Rohingyas are sheltered in camps administered by the United Nations, but hundreds of thousands more live undocumented in squalid, makeshift camps or scattered around southeast Bangladesh.
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.description: It is the first time the country has conducted a census of the refugees who have poured across the border fleeing persecution in Myanmar.
item.dc:creator: MAHER SATTAR

item.title: Bob Kerrey’s War Record Fuels Debate in Vietnam on His Role at New University
item.media:description: Former Senator Bob Kerrey, board chairman of the new Fulbright University Vietnam, being presented with the school’s license during a ceremony in Ho Chi Minh City, Vietnam, last month.
item.description: Some question whether Mr. Kerrey, a former senator who has admitted that he and commandos he led in 1969 killed women and children, should lead Fulbright University Vietnam.
item.dc:creator: RICHARD C. PADDOCK
item.category: War Crimes, Genocide and Crimes Against Humanity

item.title: From Paris to Bavaria, Heavy Rains Cause Deadly Floods
item.media:description: Inundated streets in Simbach am Inn, southern Germany, on Thursday.
item.description: About 5,000 people across France have been evacuated, and the Louvre and Musée d’Orsay announced closings. Meanwhile, rains have claimed several lives in Germany.
item.dc:creator: AURELIEN BREEDEN and KATARINA JOHANNSEN

item.title: Letter From Europe: Britain Is Losing Its Religion, or at Least Its Official One
item.media:description: A Christmas Day service at Canterbury Cathedral last year. Across Britain, pews that fill for the holidays are often half-empty in the intervening weeks and months.
item.description: The Anglican God inherited over generations from Henry VIII’s day has long ceased to represent an exclusive franchise.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL

item.title: Saudi Oil Chief Khalid al-Falih Tells OPEC Changes Are Coming
item.media:description: Saudi Arabia’s oil minister, Khalid al-Falih, speaks to reporters before the start of Thursday’s OPEC meeting.
item.description: The message came after the cartel decide to maintain high levels of production, citing the recent rise in prices and signs that the global petroleum glut might be easing.
item.dc:creator: STANLEY REED
item.category: Organization of the Petroleum Exporting Countries

item.title: North Korea’s Missile Tests Timed to Bolster Standing With China, Analysts Say
item.description: The country has conducted a series of unsuccessful launches, said to reflect a frantic drive by the country’s leader, Kim Jong-un, ahead of talks with Beijing.
item.dc:creator: CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Jinshan Journal: Rare Visit to Taiwan by Siberian Crane Is a Bird-Watcher’s Dream
item.media:description: A Siberian crane, one of fewer than 4,000 in the world and the only one known to have been spotted in Taiwan, at a rice field in the rural district of Jinshan in December.
item.description: The only Siberian crane ever seen in Taiwan set off a frenzy by sightseers, the hiring of a 24-hour guard and environmental efforts to welcome such migratory species.
item.dc:creator: AUSTIN RAMZY

item.title: King Tut’s Dagger Made of ‘Iron From the Sky,’ Researchers Say
item.media:description: The mummy of King Tutankhamen. Experts have found that the composition of iron, nickel and cobalt of a dagger discovered in the folds of his wrappings was an approximate match for a meteorite that landed in northern Egypt.
item.description: Using X-ray technology, Italian and Egyptian experts found that the blade’s composition was an approximate match for a meteorite that landed in northern Egypt.
item.dc:creator: DECLAN WALSH

item.title: U.S. Bans Commercial Trade of African Elephant Ivory
item.media:description: People in Times Square watched last year as officials with the federal Fish and Wildlife Service destroyed pieces of ivory.
item.media:credit: Sam Hodgson for The New York Times
item.description: The new rules aim to protect the endangered African elephant and curb the illegal importation of ivory into the United States.
item.dc:creator: JADA F. SMITH

item.title: U.S. Subpoenas Huawei Over Its Dealings in Iran and North Korea
item.media:description: Huawei, a major supplier of telecommunications equipment, reported revenue of about $60 billion in 2014.
item.description: Officials are questioning the Chinese telecom giant’s exports to countries covered by sanctions, amid a broader debate over global communications.
item.dc:creator: PAUL MOZUR

item.title: 24 Convicted in Massacre of Muslims During Gujarat Riots in India
item.media:description: Vehicles on fire in Ahmedabad, India, on Feb. 28, 2002, the day 69 Muslims, mostly women and children, died in a compound set ablaze by thousands of Hindu men armed with stones, iron rods and bombs.
item.description: The verdict in the latest prosecution arising from the 2002 riots did not implicate officials who were working under Narendra Modi, who led the state then.
item.dc:creator: ELLEN BARRY

item.title: Sinosphere: China’s Foreign Minister Castigates Canadian Reporter for Rights Question
item.description: The minister, Wang Yi, browbeat a journalist who asked about the Chinese government’s detention of human rights advocates and a Canadian couple accused of spying.
item.dc:creator: CHRIS BUCKLEY

item.title: E.C.B. Keeps Rates Steady as Inflation Shows Signs of Rising
item.media:description: Mario Draghi, left, the president of the European Central Bank, at a news conference Thursday. He predicted the eurozone would grow 1.6 percent this year.
item.description: The central bank, which was not expected to make significant policy moves, expressed slightly more optimism about the prospects for growth in the region
item.dc:creator: JACK EWING

item.title: What in the World: When West Africans Dress, the Fabric Is the Message
item.media:description: The designs on wax print fabric worn by West African women can be very personal.
item.description: The bold patterns and images on wax print cotton cloth that many women wear may celebrate pop culture, religion, politics or social mores.
item.dc:creator: DIONNE SEARCEY

item.title: What in the World: In Istanbul’s Taxis, Buckling Up Is an Insult
item.description: What’s the matter, don’t you trust my driving? You must be from out of town. (And, please, pay no attention to the speedometer.)
item.dc:creator: CEYLAN YEGINSU

item.title: What in the World: The Y’s and Wherefores of How Cubans Name Their Children
item.description: Many born during the Cold War were given first names beginning with Y. Experts differ as to whether it was in tribute to the Soviet Union, or in rebellion.
item.dc:creator: ELI ROSENBERG

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: The Timeless Temptation of Despots
item.description: Populists may play the system to gain power, but if they continue to undermine it, they will either destroy their nation, or it will destroy them.
item.dc:creator: NIKOS KONSTANDARAS
item.category: Coups D'Etat and Attempted Coups D'Etat

item.title: Op-Ed Columnist: If the Trans-Pacific Partnership Crumbles, China Wins
item.description: Congress should ratify the Trans-Pacific Partnership. Its failure would be a big victory for China.
item.dc:creator: ROGER COHEN

item.title: Contributing Op-Ed Writer: ‘Islamism Is Dead!’ Long Live Muslim Democrats
item.media:description: Rachid Ghannouchi at the Ennahda Congress in Tunisia in last month.
item.media:credit: Yassine Gaidi/Anadolu Agenc, via Getty Images
item.description: The country that led the Arab Spring is now the birthplace of the world’s first post-Islamist political party.
item.dc:creator: HUSSEIN IBISH

item.title: Iran’s Ruhollah Khomeini, a Man Who Shook the World
item.description: Mourning Ruhollah Khomeini, the founder of the Islamic republic, required every Iranian’s complete attention.
item.dc:creator: THOMAS ERDBRINK

item.title: With Obama in Japan, and a Puppy in Brooklyn
item.media:description: On the way to Hiroshima Peace Park to interview people gathered for President Obama’s visit, I cut through a shopping mall and saw this guy wearing a Times T-shirt. Of course we needed a picture.
item.media:credit: Adam Dean for The New York Times
item.description: Our soon-to-be Tokyo bureau chief learns to love Snapchat.
item.dc:creator: MOTOKO RICH

item.title: Have You Voted for a Far-Right Party in Europe? Share Your Thoughts
item.media:description: Supporters of the far-right Freedom Party at a rally in Vienna last month.
item.description: The Times is collecting the personal experiences of voters who have backed those groups. Whom did you support? What motivated you?
item.dc:creator: PALKO KARASZ

item.title: Alissa Rubin, 2016 Pulitzer Winner, Reports From the Front Lines
item.media:description: Alissa Rubin
item.description: Ms. Rubin has spent much of her career covering Iraq, Afghanistan and the Balkans.
item.dc:creator: MIKE McPHATE

item.title: Lens Blog: Photography Pulitzer for Coverage of Refugee Crisis
item.description: The New York Times and Thomson Reuters shared the Pulitzer Prize for breaking news photography for coverage of Europe’s refugee crisis. Jessica Rinaldi of the Boston Globe won the feature photography prize for her story of a boy who endured abuse at the hands of those he trusted.
item.dc:creator: DAVID GONZALEZ and JAMES ESTRIN
